Hi everyone, I recently had a client who had a very good score on PageSpeed, but as soon as they put several animations on the site, such as Animated Countdown, reCaptcha and other animations related to expanding content and images, the score dropped dramatically , we already have Lazy Load working with all images, but we are having trouble optimizing more, one of our backend developers said that many of the points cannot be optimized due to limitations.

I'm new to HubSpot and I'm jsut starting in HubL but I have some knowledge in this kind of optimization, but don't know how to apply in HubSpot exactly.

1- *Enable Compression on all files:* default HubSpot js loaded by HubSpot so we can't access it to compress. like form js and captcha js. but other external js, video, and image that we can compress manually.

2 - *Defer parsing of JavaScript:* - same as we can't access some HubSpot js like Google Captcha because it loaded by HubSpot. we only can render in the footer our custom js and libraries.

3 - *Optimize images*. - we can solve this issue using a lazy load image.

4 - *Leverage browser caching and expiration date in JS scripts*. -
I know this is a huge impact on speed. I am not able to reduce it here because there is most of the js loaded into cms and app connectivity. I do not know about the Expiration Date of the Scripts maybe it is set in code then I need to check it. <https://developers.google.com/speed/pagespeed/insights/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fmarketing.sfgate.com%2F&tab=desktop|This is page>

Does anyone have any tips on how to improve optimization following the recommendations of PageSpeed ​​if possible?

Hi Community - I am looking for some guidance around using multiple blog types on the same website. Can someone help, please?

- Gagan

If the goal is to get back to the original score, I would suggest using the Intersection Observer JS API to only load in the animated content once the user scrolls close to that section, essentially lazy-loading that content.

If you're trying to get as much performance as possible, it looks like almost every module on the page is using CSS and JS at the module level, which are then each included as an external asset that is render-blocking. Bundling those assets together, or putting them in an embedded <style> or <script> tag at the HTML level will lead to less requests and less blocking time.

I have redirect in my HubSpot portal that was working, it is still in my portal but no longer is working, is there any known issues with redirects not working on portals that were working

<@U01C5SCRUT1> I dont think that there is an easy way to generate different markup based on tags. If you really wanted to keep them all tied together in a single blog you could grab the tag and based off that that tag conditionally render markup. But I wouldnt recommend this approach. There are too many places where it could go wrong and it’s not so future proof.

If at all possible, I would recommend splitting the blogs up into their own blog. A blog for “Blogs”, one for “Case Studies”, one for Webinars, etc. Then its much easier to just build separate templates for them and then you can use the tags to dig a bit deeper in terms of filtering or other categorization.

Once youve made new Blogs moving them from, say “Blog” to “Case Studies” is as easy as going into the blog post settings tab and picking the correct blog domain from the url dropdown.
